text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
Revised to include Interim Guidance AP-08-1118-0013, Appeals Conference Procedures, and editorial changes as noted in the table below:

Incorporated IG AP-08-1118-0013 revisions to ac- commodate taxpayer and representative requests for in-person conference. Deleted (7) - (11) to input ACDS CARATS codes for approval of in-person conference transfers.

Control of Non-Collection Due Process (CDP) (

) Purpose. This IRM section explains the receipt and control procedures for Collection Due Process (CDP) Offer in Compromise (OIC) cases worked by and Appeals. Procedures for OICs that are worked by Appeals during CDP are discussed in IRM
, Alternatives to Collection Action. (
) Audience. Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) working Offer in cases. (
) Policy Owner. Policy, Planning, Quality & Analysis is under the Director of Case and Operations Support. (
) Program Owner. Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals Organization and is the Director of Policy, Planning, Quality & Analysis. (

) Contact Information. Appeals employees follow established procedures on to Contact an Analyst. All other employees should contact the Product Owner provided on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. (
) An OIC is an agreement between a taxpayer and the government that tax liability in exchange for payment of less than the full amount owed.

) The Director, Policy, is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) Policy is comprised of two teams of analysts:
) Collection Appeals & ing Policy, and
) Examination Appeals Policy. The analyst(s) responsible for the Offer in Compromise program report to the manager for Collection Policy. (

) This section provides guidance for the receipt and control of non Collection Due Process (CDP) offers in compromise (OICs). Procedures for OICs received as an alternative to collection in a CDP or equivalent hearing (EH) case are found in IRM
, Alternatives to Collection Action. (

) Field Collection, Field Examination and the Centralized Offer in Compromise (COIC) sites forward taxpayer’s protests of rejected offers. The campus Appeals offices in Brookhaven and Memphis work the bulk of the cases from the COIC sites. The most complex COIC offers and Compliance ﬁeld source cases are generally assigned to the Appeals office that covers the taxpayer’s geographical location . (
) Within
days of the ATE’s receipt of a rejected OIC case in Appeals, Letter
, Appeals Offer in Compromise Acknowledgement and Conference will be mailed to the taxpayer. See IRM
), Pre-Conference erations, for a complete list of information that is communicated through
Enclose Publication
, Overview of Appeals Process, and Publica- tion

, Appeals - Introduction to Alternative Dispute Resolution. The purpose of this letter is to: • Advise the taxpayer of receipt of the case in Appeals • Provide the Appeals contact person’s name and telephone number • Explain what the taxpayer can expect from Appeals during the appeal process
Advise the taxpayer of receipt of the case in Appeals
Provide the Appeals contact person’s name and telephone number
Explain what the taxpayer can expect from Appeals during the appeal process
Explain what Appeals generally expects from the taxpayer during the Appeals process
Schedule the conference

If initial contact is made by telephone, cover all of the items above, which are contained in the Letter 5576. Document the case activity record accord- ingly. See also IRM 8.23.3.3.1(7), Pre-Conference Considerations.
Note: Appeals campus sites should not enclose Publication
with Letter
because OICs considered at an Appeals campus site are not presently eligible for alternative dispute resolution processes. (
) See IRM
, Offer in Compromise (OIC) Case Carding, for initial case receipt guidance for Account and Processing Support (APS) personnel. (

) Appeals receives rejected OIC cases from a variety of sources. Assignments should be based upon case complexity and the experience level of the ATE. If the complexity of a certain case extends beyond the technical skills available in a particular location, the case should be reassigned.
See IRM 8.20.5.30, Offer in Compromise (OIC) Case Carding, for initial case receipt guidance for Account and Processing Support (APS) personnel.
of Non-Collection Due Process (CDP) page (
) Appeals management will occasionally assign or re-assign cases to other areas to effectively manage inventory levels. (
) OICs rejected by a COIC site may be resolved through written or telephone contact. In working these cases, you must be knowledgeable with this IRM as well as with IRM
, Offer in Compromise, IRM
, Installment Agree- ments, IRM
, Financial Analysis, and IRM
, Currently Not (

) Higher graded OICs are generally more complex and require more detailed ﬁnancial analysis skills, familiarity with asset valuation techniques, and sound negotiation and communication skills. In working these more complex cases, you must have an in-depth understanding of the following: • the impact and priority of the federal tax lien, • the impact of state and local statutes on asset ownership, valuation equities, • enforced collection actions such as levy and administrative seizure sale, • judicial actions such as a suit to foreclose a federal tax lien or reduce tax claim to a judgment, and • Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) liability issues. (

) OICs ﬁled on the basis of Effective Tax Administration (ETA) or Doubt as to Collectibility with Special Circumstances (DCSC) require a level of sufficient to consider the facts of the case as described above. (
) The OIC case grading matrix is found in IRM
, Resource Guide for Managers - Appeals Managers Procedures. (
) If the taxpayer requests an in-person conference in response to Letter
, grant the request, in accordance with IRM
) There is no separate Appeals policy for OIC cases and in-person hearings. OIC conferences are usually held by telephone or correspondence. (
) A taxpayer or representative might request to have a case transferred to the Appeals office closest to the taxpayer for an in-person conference. Case transfer procedures are found in IRM
, Transfer Procedures. date a taxpayer’s or representative’s request for an in-person conference by following procedures in IRM
, Conference Practice and IRM
, Circuit Riding and IRM
, Virtual Service Delivery Note: Revenue Procedure
was released December
, creating a nationwide post-Appeals mediation (PAM) program for ﬁeld Offer in mise (OIC) cases. IRM
, Post Appeals Mediation Procedures for Col- lection Cases, supplements Revenue Procedure
and was updated March

The alternative dispute resolution (ADR) programs are signed to supplement and not replace the standard appeals process. Ap- peals’ primary emphasis is on the standard appeals process and not on ADR. OIC cases will not be transferred from a campus location for the pur- pose of participating in PAM.

Appeals management will occasionally assign or re-assign cases to other areas to effectively manage inventory levels.

Higher graded OICs are generally more complex and require more detailed ﬁnancial analysis skills, familiarity with asset valuation techniques, and sound negotiation and communication skills. In working these more complex cases, you must have an in-depth understanding of the following:

the impact and priority of the federal tax lien, the impact of state and local statutes on asset ownership, valuation equities, enforced collection actions such as levy and administrative seizure sale, judicial actions such as a suit to foreclose a federal tax lien or reduce tax claim to a judgment, and Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) liability issues.
There is no separate Appeals policy for OIC cases and in-person OIC conferences are usually held by telephone or correspondence.
Offer in (

) When determining whether to transfer a case, the taxpayer and business addresses must be physical, and not a post office box or similar address. Note: A homeless individual will not have a physical address. For transfer these taxpayers may use the address of a friend, relative, employer, P.O. Box, authorized representative or Low-Income Tax Clinic (LITC). (

) A taxpayer or representative who believes an adverse decision is likely or imminent might request to have a case transferred to the Appeals office to the taxpayer after engaging in substantive negotiations with you or after conference has been held with you. It is important to point out to the during an initial telephone contact that any request for an in-person must be made before meaningful negotiations begin subject to the in-person conference provisions of IRM
, Conference and Issue Resolution. will not be accommodated once a conference has been held. (
) IRM

, Circuit Riding, and related subsections contain Appeals’ circuit riding procedures. In certain cases, where the taxpayer has requested and been granted an in-person conference, Appeals will accommodate taxpayers by circuit riding. Such conferences will be held at the nearest Appeals office or other location, following the procedures noted above. (

) One of the following three Sub-Action Codes must be used when the request is denied for a face-to-face conference. Sub-Action Code Deﬁnition DC Denied - Compliance Issues DF Transfer or reassignment was denied because taxpayer raised only frivolous issues. DO Transfer or reassignment was denied for other reasons. (
) The deﬁnitions for these codes are also available on the ACDS Utilities under “CARATS Operational Deﬁnitions”. (

) This section provides procedures for preliminary case review to make sure offer is ready for Appeals’ consideration. If the offer was sent to Appeals and maturely, it must be returned to the referring office. You should follow the procedures in IRM
, Evaluation of Offers in Compromise, after ing the case is ready for Appeals’ consideration. Note: Most premature referrals should, generally, be returned to the originating Compliance office within
days of Appeals’ receipt of the case. See IRM
, Premature Referral Issues, for details on premature referral including those that must be sent back even after
days, due to jurisdic- tional issues. (
) You must screen new OIC receipts to make sure: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

physical address.
One of the following three Sub-Action Codes must be used when the transfer request is denied for a face-to-face conference.

), Rejection to determine if the appeal is timely. If the appeal was not timely, it must be returned as a premature referral because Appeals does not have the tion to consider the appeal. See IRM

(e) states there must be an independent administrative review of rejection of an OIC before such rejection is communicated to the taxpayer,

) provides that an offer in compromise has not rejected until IRS issues a written notice to the taxpayer or his advising of: • The rejection, • The reason(s) for rejection, and • The right to an appeal. See IRM
, Premature Referral - Jurisdictional Issues, for on what to do if the taxpayer’s appeal pre-dates the actual rejection of the offer.

(e) states there must be an independent administrative review of any rejection of an OIC before such rejection is communicated to the taxpayer, and

The taxpayer receives credit for the TIPRA payment and application fee that were paid with the initial offer, although an additional TIPRA payment may be required if the amended offer includes an increase in the offer amount, or change in terms. This is considered an amended offer, and no separate processability determination will need to be made by Collec- tion. (

(f) is closed. Thus, any“ reopened” case, whether due to IRS error or not, will not have a TIPRA statute. See IRM

, Return Reconsideration. This may of importance where Appeals secures an OIC case on which there was not a decision (rejection, return, withdrawal) made by Collection prior to its assign- ment in Appeals, as may be seen in (

)(B)(ii) because the taxpayer failed to make the second or later in- stallment due on a periodic payment OIC (see IRM

months after the date of the submission of the offer. Any period during which any tax liability that is the subject of the OIC is in dispute in any judicial proceeding shall not be taken into account in determining the expiration of the
-month period. The date of submission of an offer for purposes of section

-month period during which any tax liability that is the subject of the OIC is in dispute in any judicial proceeding, there are no means to extend or suspend the
-month TIPRA period. The

- month period includes whatever time a case may be pending in Counsel awaiting their opinion on an acceptance recommendation. There is no tory basis for the taxpayer and the Service to enter into any sort of agree- ment to extend or suspend the
-month period. (
) There are two instances where Appeals may receive an OIC without a ﬁnal decision ﬁrst being made by Collection, and thus, have an open TIPRA (see also table (

) below): • OIC submitted as an alternative to collection in a CDP or EH case. • OIC processed as a single, processable OIC ﬁling for two (or more) entities, and which is in need of perfection to create a second or third related offer. See IRM
, Processing Forms
and Initial Offer Payments . In this case, when the second or third OIC is received, a new TC

date and TIPRA statute date will be present. If the related offer(s) is secured by Appeals, then since the new offer(s) was never rejected by Compliance, it will have an open TIPRA statute. New offers must immediately be sent to COIC for a processability determination. Note: Only secure additional
forms after you have determined to recommend
Note: Except for suspension of the
-month period during which any tax liability that is the subject of the OIC is in dispute in any judicial proceeding, there are no means to extend or suspend the
-month TIPRA period. The

- month period includes whatever time a case may be pending in Counsel awaiting their opinion on an acceptance recommendation. There is no statu- tory basis for the taxpayer and the Service to enter into any sort of agree- ment to extend or suspend the
-month period.

Except for suspension of the 24-month period during which any tax liability that is the subject of the OIC is in dispute in any judicial proceeding, there are no means to extend or suspend the 24-month TIPRA period. The 24- month period includes whatever time a case may be pending in Counsel awaiting their opinion on an acceptance recommendation. There is no statu- tory basis for the taxpayer and the Service to enter into any sort of agree- ment to extend or suspend the 24-month period.

OIC submitted as an alternative to collection in a CDP or EH case. OIC processed as a single, processable OIC ﬁling for two (or more) entities, and which is in need of perfection to create a second or third related offer. See IRM
, Processing Forms
and Initial Offer Payments . In this case, when the second or third OIC is received, a new TC

date and TIPRA statute date will be present. If the related offer(s) is secured by Appeals, then since the new offer(s) was never rejected by Compliance, it will have an open TIPRA statute. New offers must immediately be sent to COIC for a processability determination.

Various types of offers or offers with speciﬁc issues are assigned unique ACDS feature codes. If the following case types or issues are present, check the OIC WUNO to make sure it reﬂects the appropriate ACDS feature code:
• DO = Potential default case on previously accepted offer • DP = OIC that is part of a related CDP or EH case (same ’DP’ code should also be on the CDP/EH WUNO - see IRM

, Collection Due Process - Feature Codes) • ETA = Effective Tax Administration offer • LI = OIC based upon doubt as to liability • SP = OIC based upon doubt as to collectibility with “special circum- stances” If it is determined that the case is ready for Appeals’ consideration, send the
If it is determined that the case is ready for Appeals’ consideration, send the Letter 5576, if one was not previously sent and document such in the case

) Sometimes taxpayers have liabilities for multiple entities. For various reasons, it is also sometimes the case that these related offers are submitted by taxpayers after an initial offer is submitted for a different entity. During the course of the consideration of an offer by you, if you become aware that there is an open, related offer under consideration elsewhere in Appeals, then coor- dinate with whomever the related case is assigned to accept transfer of the related case, so that the cases may share a consolidated assignment, review and disposition. (

) For purposes of this subsection, related cases will be those related to any or individual offer as follows: a. Any additional offer involving the separate liabilities of one or both spouses (e.g. sole-proprietorship liabilities, trust fund recovery penalties, liabilities from a prior marriage). Note: In a situation involving married taxpayers where two separate offers jointly owed liabilities are under consideration, the offers will be considered related only if the taxpayers are domiciled together. b. Any additional offer involving one or more closely-held corporations or LLCs owned by one or both spouses in the joint or individual offer. Note: Appeals will not accept immediate assignment from Collection of any offer that appears in example (

)(b). Such cases are considered related for purposes of consolidating assignment once in Appeals. There is no authority for Appeals to accept assignment of these cases from Collection unless the taxpayer has ﬁrst undergone the administrative review and rejection process under IRC
) If an initial offer is already assigned to you, coordinate with Collection to diately accept assignment of any related offer that ﬁts example (

)(a) above. Any undeveloped information that is included with a related offer that is trans- ferred to Appeals will be considered “new information” submitted to Appeals. If necessary, undeveloped information will be sent to Collection following the cedures in IRM
, Request and Review of Supplemental - Collection Issue Offers. (
) Per IRM
, Liabilities to be Compromised, and IRM
, Deﬁnition of a Compromised Liability, all assessed taxpayer liabilities should be in any offer acceptance. If related liabilities exist (as in example

(a) above), an offer cannot be accepted that does not also include offer(s) for related li- abilities. Therefore, if you are accepting an offer, secure the necessary forms and payments needed for the related offer, and forward the package to COIC for the necessary processing. COIC will generally determine processibility within
hours. (
) If an initial offer is already assigned in Appeals, Appeals will not accept immediate assignment from Compliance of any related offer that appears in example (

)(b) and its associated Note. Such cases are considered related only for purposes of consolidating assignment once in Appeals. There is no authority for Appeals to accept assignment of these cases from Compliance unless the taxpayer has ﬁrst undergone the administrative review and process under IRC
Any additional offer involving one or more closely-held corporations or LLCs owned by one or both spouses in the joint or individual offer.
Control of Non-Collection Due Process (CDP) page (

) When you encounter a situation where a correction needs to be made to or IDRS, APS can input the correction. Submit your request via e-mail to the campus location that is responsible to process the closure of your case one of the mailboxes below : • *AP-COS-APS-West-FRS ACDS Update Request • *AP-COS-APS-East-MEM ACDS Update Request • *AP-COS-APS-East-HOL ACDS Update Request (

) This section discusses the Appeals hearing officer’s responsibilities in ing and processing premature referrals. Non-CDP OIC protests must be reviewed to determine if there are reasons why the case should be closed returned as a premature referral. A case is closed as a premature referral the jurisdictional and other reasons outlined below. Note: A case will not be returned as a premature referral on the basis of your clusion that Collection did not fully develop certain issues. Review Collection’s development of the issue versus information and testimony provided by the taxpayer, and make the decision based on those factors. (
) Non-CDP OIC receipts must be reviewed to make sure the appeal is timely. taxpayer has

calendar days from the date of the rejection letter to - an administrative Appeals hearing. If the appeal was not timely, it must be returned as a premature referral because Appeals does not have the tion to consider the appeal. (

) Occasionally, an appeal is received and the postmark, meter or fax sion date is illegible or the envelope is missing. To determine timeliness if postmark, meter or fax transmission date is illegible, or the envelope is missing: a. Mailing: Ask the taxpayer when he or she mailed the request. If the taxpayer appears credible, use that date. If you can not reach the taxpayer or the taxpayer is not credible, subtract
days for regular and

days for overseas mail from the IRS received date. b. Faxed: Use the date the Service received the request unless the taxpayer can show otherwise as in (a). c. If there is no IRS received date, use the signature date. d. If there is no IRS received date or signature date, consider timely if received in Appeals within
days of date required to be timely. Note: IRC
and IRC

CFR

(c)(iii)(B) provides that such must be legible and dated on or before the due date and the appeal must received not later than the time when a letter sent by the same class of would ordinarily have been received if it were sent from the same point of origin by the U.S. Post Office on the last day for timely mailing the appeal. , if the

Mailing: Ask the taxpayer when he or she mailed the request. If the taxpayer appears credible, use that date. If you can not reach the taxpayer or the taxpayer is not credible, subtract
days for regular and

days for overseas mail from the IRS received date. Faxed: Use the date the Service received the request unless the taxpayer can show otherwise as in (a). If there is no IRS received date, use the signature date. If there is no IRS received date or signature date, consider timely if received in Appeals within
days of date required to be timely.
IRC
and IRC
apply to OIC appeals. Per IRC
, if the appeal is mailed within

calendar days after the date of Compliance’s rejection letter, it is a timely appeal. It must be postmarked so that the mailing date can be established. If the postmark is made by a non-U.S. Postal Service system such as a private postage meter stamp or a non-USPS carrier such as UPS or Fedex,
CFR

(c)(iii)(B) provides that such postmark must be legible and dated on or before the due date and the appeal must be received not later than the time when a letter sent by the same class of mail would ordinarily have been received if it were sent from the same point of origin by the U.S. Post Office on the last day for timely mailing the appeal. Per IRC
, if the
th day falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, a request for appeal is considered timely if mailed on the next business day.

postpones certain time-sensitive acts when a person is serving the armed forces, in support of the armed forces, in an area designated by the President by Executive Order as a combat zone, or when deployed outside the United States while participating in an operation designated by the Secretary of Defense as a contingency operation. If the taxpayer’s written appeal pre-dates the actual rejection of the offer, it is not a valid appeal under IRC 7122 and its regulations. Before returning such an offer to Collection as a premature referral, check the case ﬁle, the AOIC eCase data and ICS histories to see if the taxpayer submitted a separate and timely written appeal within the prescribed time period. If the only written appeal pre-dates the actual rejection of the offer, the appeal is not timely and it must be returned as a premature referral.
These less common instances identify cases that should be returned as a premature referral because Appeals lacks the jurisdictional authority to consider the protest:

premature referral because Appeals lacks the jurisdictional authority to consider the protest: a. If a timely appeal is signed by an unauthorized representative or other third party, and not signed by the taxpayer. b. If a timely protest is received, but the rejection letter was signed by a lower level authority than what is required by Delegation Order

(e.g. a Territory Manager’s signature is required but the Group Manager signs the rejection Letter). c. If the tax liability is paid in full before direct or written contact with Appeals. d. If under IRC
(f) and Notice
, the
month period has before the taxpayer withdrew the offer, or the IRS returned/rejected the offer. A Form

, Statute Expiration Report, or other statute reporting method is not needed in this instance. e. If the taxpayer ﬁled bankruptcy before the Collection offer examiner ad- vised the taxpayer of the proposed rejection (documented either verbally or in writing), the offer should have been returned without appeal rights per IRM
, Bankruptcy. See IRM

, Bankruptcy Consid- erations, if the taxpayer ﬁled bankruptcy after the offer was rejected. f. A new offer is received by the Service after a Notice of Determination or Decision Letter was issued in a CDP or EH case. Such an offer would not be associated with the CDP case as the CDP is now considered closed.
Receipt and Control of Non-Collection Due Process (CDP) Offers 8.23.2 page
g. A new offer is received by the Service after the issuance of a CDP clos- ing letter with an executed Form

Such an offer would not be as- sociated with the CDP case as the CDP is now considered closed h. A new offer is received by the Service after the issuance of a closing ter for a withdrawn CDP or EH case. Such an offer would not be ated with the CDP case as the CDP is now considered closed i. A new offer is received after a related OIC was closed in any manner other than acceptance. See IRM

, Assignment of Related for related offers. Such an offer would not be associated with the related offer as the related offer is now considered closed. Note: If any of these jurisdictional issues are identiﬁed more than
days after peals received the case, the Appeals hearing officer or the ATM should tact the Collection manager and explain why the case will be returned as a premature referral. (

) Your initial case review may show that Collection did not sufficiently identify reasons why a case was referred to Appeals. Your feedback should specify why the referral was insufficient and include any IRM (or other) requirements that Collection overlooked or failed to follow in documenting the reason for referral to Appeals. A case will not be returned as a premature referral on the basis of your conclusion that Collection did not fully develop certain issues. In those situations you will make a decision after reviewing Collection’s develop- ment of the issue against the information and testimony provided by the taxpayer. (

) In some cases, Collection may erroneously conclude that Appeals previously determined the tax liability and not address it. For example, this can occur if earlier case was listed on the Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) as docketed and closed using closing code

This could mean the case dismissed without addressing the liability. If you conclude the liability was not previously determined by Appeals, send the case back to the Brookhaven DATL unit alerting them that the case has an open TIPRA statute by using Form
entitled, “Appeals Returning DATL OIC (CC
)”, which is on the Appeals OIC Web Page. If the liability was established by the Tax Court, you should also alert the DATL unit to that fact. (
) If the case involves unpaid trust fund taxes, the assessment statute date (ASED) is not suspended by the offer in compromise. For an OIC received by the Service after February
, IRM

), Offers Operating Businesses, states: a. either the trust fund portion of the taxes must be paid, b. the TFRP must be assessed against all responsible persons, c. the trust fund package was forwarded for assessment, Note: Do not return a case as a premature referral if Collection has clearly documented either a non-assertion determination or that trust fund balance is below assessment requirements, or if the ASED has expired and no TFRP was assessed. (
) Other non-jurisdictional premature referral situations include:

Such an offer would not be associ- ated with the CDP case as the CDP is now considered closed A new offer is received after a related OIC was closed in any manner other than acceptance. See IRM
, Assignment of Related Offers, for related offers. Such an offer would not be associated with the related offer as the related offer is now considered closed.

Control of Non-Collection Due Process (CDP) page (

) When a collectibility OIC is considered and rejected by Collection, the tion of the case as a rejection indicates that the taxpayer was in current compliance at the time of rejection. If not, Collection should have closed the or case to the taxpayer as a “return” with no appeal right. Therefore, you will consider the taxpayer as being in veriﬁed tax compliance whenever a case is received, and will not request estimated tax payments or even if those appear to have been delinquent or miscalculated prior to the rejection of the case. (
) You will not return a case as a premature referral to Collection to address issues indicated in (
) above. (
) You will not monitor a taxpayer’s ongoing tax compliance while a rejected is under consideration, except as speciﬁed in IRM

, Taxpayer Compli- ance Issues, and its related subsections. Note: If the amount of estimated tax payments or withholdings is disputed in a payer’s appeal, then you may verify them as expense items on the Income/ Expense Table, but will not otherwise address these issues. The Form contains tax compliance provisions which the taxpayer must follow while an offer is under consideration. (
) Because of the risk of rapid and substantial losses to the government due to the failure to make Federal Tax Deposit (FTD) payments, you should follow IRM

, Offer in Compromise, Return, Terminate, Withdraw, and Reject Processing, with respect to veriﬁcation of FTD compliance, and In- Business Trust Fund (IBTF) return ﬁling compliance, but with some noted exceptions. (
) As explained in IRM

, Premature Referral - Jurisdictional Issues, above, when a collectibility issue OIC is considered and rejected by the disposition of the case as a rejection indicates that the taxpayer was in current FTD and ﬁling compliance at the time of the rejection. If not, should have closed the case to the taxpayer as a “return” with no appeal Therefore, you will consider the taxpayer as being in veriﬁed FTD whenever a rejected case is received, and will not demand federal tax to be made even if those appear to have been delinquent or miscalculated prior to the rejection (See also (
) below). (
) You will not return a case to Collection as a premature referral to address issues indicated in (
) or (
) above. (
) You will not monitor the taxpayer’s regular FTD schedule. However, if you recognize a new IBTF assessment while you are considering the offer, you should give the taxpayer

days to pay the entire liability (including and interest) so that the consideration of the offer may continue. If the taxpayer does not pay the new liability in full, you should either sustain rejection of the offer or, in unique circumstances (left to Appeals’ sole discre- tion), determine to include the liability in the offer and proceed with consideration of the case. See also IRM
, When a Taxpayer Does Remain in Compliance. (
) If an IBTF tax return becomes delinquent while an OIC case is under your sideration, you should: Internal Revenue Manual

A taxpayer submitting a Periodic Payment Offer is required to make the periodic installment payments proposed in such offer. If the taxpayer fails to make the periodic installment payments they proposed on Form

before the Collection offer examiner advised the taxpayer of the proposed rejection (either verbally or in writing), the case should be returned as a premature referral for Compliance to secure the necessary TIPRA payments.

The TIPRA requirement for a taxpayer to make proposed periodic installment payments while a Periodic Payment offer is being considered ends when Collection issues the rejection letter. , Application Fees, Offer Terms, Payments and Deposits, and IRM

problems that may affect the acceptability of an offer will generally only include instances in which the taxpayer failed to:
• Timely ﬁle all required returns • Timely pay all tax, penalties and interest due on returns assessed after the offer was received by Appeals (see (

) below), or • Make payments required for a Periodic Payment OIC proposal. In the instances above, it is important for you to provide the taxpayer with instructions as to exactly what is required of them, speciﬁc deadlines, and the consequence if the compliance issue is not promptly resolved. ) above, Appeals generally does not require a processible offer to be returned or rejected because a previously unﬁled or delinquent IMF return produces a new liability, or because any other new assessment is while the offer is being considered. New liabilities may be included on the Form
, and consideration of the appeal will continue. See IRM
, Taxpayer Compliance Issues, and related subsections for exceptions. The following examples illustrate where a new liability will generally be included in

In Appeals, a return is ﬁled that was delinquent before the case came to Appeals, and the return produces a new liability. Since this issue should have been addressed before the case came to Appeals, the new liability will be included in the offer.

Example: A trust fund recovery penalty assessment is made against a taxpayer who has an otherwise viable offer proposal under consideration, and a good overall compliance record in recent years. In this case, it is prudent to continue negotiation of the offer and include the new assessment(s).

An assessment is made against a taxpayer who has an otherwise viable offer proposal under consideration, and a good compliance record in recent years. The offer has been under consideration for some time and the Service has expended much time and resources considering the case. Past collection efforts against the taxpayer have yielded very little funds over the years. In this case, it is prudent to continue negotiation of the offer and include the new assessment.

An assessment is made against taxpayers who have an otherwise viable offer proposal under consideration, and a good compliance record in recent years. The assessment resulted from the liquidation of a small retirement account that was used by the taxpayers for necessary living expenses. The taxpayers have insufficient liquid assets to immediately pay the new assessment. In this case, it is prudent to continue negotia
tion of the offer and include the new assessment.
) Per IRM

, Conference and Settlement Practices, one of the four primary obligations you have in a non-CDP OIC appeal is to offer the taxpayer an opportunity for the Appeals conference that he/she asked for under IRC

). Non-compliance with a ﬁling and/or payment requirement does not preclude you from giving the taxpayer an opportunity for a conference. Even if the taxpayer does not remedy a compliance issue prior to or at the scheduled conference, the opportunity for a conference must be given. If the taxpayer does not take part in the conference when scheduled, you do not need to the non-CDP taxpayer a second opportunity.
See also IRM 8.23.1.3 for more information about granting extensions of time in non-CDP OIC case.
